fields.description: When starting a remote SC it is possible that an Out of Memory will occur during JIBX binding creation which doesnâ€™t allow the SC to start.
fields.summary: SC failure to start in rare cases

comments.body: [~sjones] Just to make sure I understand what this fix is doing.  The ordering on of the jars on the file system changes with each build and because the bindings order was also variable we saw this issue on indeterminate installs. What this fix does is remove the binding order as a variable with the sorted treeMap so that if we see this issue it will be on 'all' installs of a particular build. If we see this binding issue i.e. "org.jibx.runtime.JiBXException" we need to rebuild.

The ordering of the jars of the file system varies between installs, but it does not depend on the build as far as I know. The fix ensures the same class files will be generated for all installations of a particular build and if this issue does occur then a rebuild is required.
@Steve Jones  Thanks Steve . I am going to go ahead and check this into 3.4.2
[~mmunn1] note that the binding compilation order change is unlikely to address the out of memory error reported for this issue (I do not know how to reproduce the out of memory error)
[~sjones] Yes, the "Out of memory" error  was a separate issue seen at the customer site and is a red herring as far as the binding issue is concerned.

I can verify that nightlies fixes this issue.  Per discussion with [~viglesias] and [~kedwards] build a 3.4 cloud specifically to test this and thankfully (?!) I ran into the issue immediately; my CLC was unable to start due to the binding errors.  I upgraded to nightlies and the CLC started just fine, with no errors whilst compiling bindings.
With 3.4.2 just under a month out, can we consider a hotfix for this?  I think the user experience is dented substantially by this and it might be a good idea to get a fix out to users ASAP.
Victor Iglesias I believe there is a need to get this fix out to a couple of our bigger clients faster than waiting till 3.4.2. Is it possible to issue a hotfix?
Closing based on experience so far in GA runs and manual testing, as well as the experience from [~lwade]. Will reopen if we see this again.
Reverted to in QA based on request from [~jmille] and [~viglesias]

[~jmille]

Can you please add the package info from when you ran into this issue?

[~viglesias]

Installed Packages
Name        : eucalyptus
Arch        : x86_64
Version     : 3.4.2
Release     : 0.0.536.20140124git5ff34788.el6
Size        : 2.4 M
Repo        : installed
From repo   : /eucalyptus-3.4.2-0.0.536.20140124git5ff34788.el6.x86_64

[~kedwards]]
All packages used in my current setup come from the given URL :
http://packages.release.eucalyptus-systems.com/yum/builds/eucalyptus/branch/maint-3.4-testing/centos/6/x86_64/

Probably worth mentioning again that the fix for this issue does not prevent the problem occurring. The fix for this issue is intended to make the problem occur consistently on all installs of any given build, so it is easier to detect in QA and we don't ship a broken build.

[~sjones]

I have a build that succeeded from the same packages:
Installed Packages
Name        : eucalyptus
Arch        : x86_64
Version     : 3.4.2
Release     : 0.0.536.20140124git5ff34788.el6
Size        : 2.4 M
Repo        : installed
From repo   : eucalyptus
Summary     : Elastic Utility Computing Architecture
URL         : http://www.eucalyptus.com
License     : GPLv3
Description : Eucalyptus is a service overlay that implements elastic computing
            : using existing resources. The goal of Eucalyptus is to allow sites
            : with existing clusters and server infrastructure to co-host an elastic
            : computing service that is interface-compatible with Amazon AWS.
            :
            : This package contains the common parts; you will need to install at
            : least one of the cloud controller (cloud), cluster controller (cc),
            : node controller (nc), storage controller (sc), or walrus packages as well.

[root@e-06 ~]#
Moving to fixed. This issue has not been reported or seen in GA runs or QA testing in a couple weeks.
